texts.definition: Changes in characters' abilities, skills, or powers as part of gameplay.
markups: <style="Definition">Changes in characters' abilities, skills, or powers as part of gameplay.</style>

Games that include characters under players' control often make it possible for these to have <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>. On a general level, this can either be in the form of becoming more likely to succeed with actions, or make actions that were previously unavailable possible. It is typically explained within the setting of the game as the development of powers or skills, possibly through access to new tools, or the change of other characters' attitude towards that character.

The characters in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sims%20series">Sims series</link></style> have numeric values of how well they are at the existing skills, and increasing these are a form of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>. Improving (or possibly decreasing) relationship values towards other characters can also be seen as a form of development, as can the increase in material wealth. Using a less complex model, the influence of virtual pets that <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tamagochi">Tamagochi</link></style> toys  allow players to have can be seen as a similar form of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>.

Many <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> allow various ways of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>. Some allow increases in individual skills (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">Hârnmaster</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>) while other use character levels (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>) as the main measure, but practical all let the acquisition of tools and equipment affect mechanical aspects of gameplay and the development of social relations affect narration or social actions. Gaining new powers is also common, e.g. both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> supports this. The various systems have carried over to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer-based%20Roleplaying%20Games">Computer-based Roleplaying Games</link></style>, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> letting skill improvements drive level improvement while gaining levels in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> allow players to give their characters new powers.

Both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl">Bloodbowl</link></style> and the computer-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bloodbowl%20(computer%20game)">version</link></style> of the game have rules for individual players gaining experience points, and, when enough are acquired, new star player powers.

<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> is defined by two characteristics: what caused the development and what effect the development has on the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (which may be <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style>). Common causes for <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> are as effects of  <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>. This is usually done by various forms of <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> (e.g. "experience points") to complete <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals; <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style> is a common way of structuring this that supports <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leveling">Leveling</link></style> and can be found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>. What specific events lead to <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can vary: while many games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, provide "experience points" for winning <style="Link"><link="combat">Combats</link></style> or finishing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, others make the use of <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> the prime mechanism for improving these (this is found in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style> and to a certain extent in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">Hârnmaster</link></style>) while other still simply make it an effect of the unfolding of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>. A specific case related to use of <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> is to reward <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> by making this lead to <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>.

The actual development is often by explicitly affecting the characters possibilities to influence the game state, most typically by changes in the <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style> of a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style>. This can be in the form of <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, which may either expand a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> or increase <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>. The changes in abilities may also be explained as changes in which <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> have.  A form of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can also be achieved by letting them have access to better <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>. Providing <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> in this way opens up for it being lost through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> and makes it easier latter have, maybe temporary, <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> may also take the form of joining <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style> or having improved relation to them (see for example <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Oblivion">Oblivion</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> for examples of this), and this provide another explanation to have <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, e.g. not being able to attack <style="Link"><link="factions">Faction</link></style> members or innocent bystanders. These kinds of <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> do not need to be explicitly enforced, they can instead be enforced through <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>.

Regardless of what the actual development is, there are several ways of modulating it. Letting players chose one or a few options regarding <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> it a way to give them a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> in the <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> but restricted through a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resource</link></style> of "development points" (see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> for a couple of different examples of how this can be done). Having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Classes">Character Classes</link></style> in games is a way to limit which <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> can be affected by <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> based on a thematic stance, and <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style> can be used to make individual variations. Making the advancements into <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> is a easy way to make the choices more serious for the players. <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>, especially of <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, can be limited by <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diminishing%20Returns">Diminishing Returns</link></style> to modulate the increase rates over time - for example, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skill</link></style> increase may happen often when one is a novice but rarely when one is an expert. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> implements this by having different costs for different <style="Link"><link="skills">Skill</link></style> levels while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style> does it by making the chance of improving <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style> less the higher the level already is.

<style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> since it makes players' try to fulfill the goals of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and succeeding or failing with these can be a form of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>. It should be pointed out that this provides a motivation for players to strive to <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> that may have little or nothing to do with gameplay empowerment but rather with affecting the unfolding of <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. An extreme form of this is <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style>, where the successes of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> takes a back seat to creating a good story.

To maintain <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, the development of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should in many cases be noticeable in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> through how their associated <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> look. In some cases this is more or less automatically present, e.g. when <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> is through the equipping of new <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, but the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fable%20series">Fable series</link></style> shows how the appearance of players' <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> can change due to how they develop. These change may in most cases only be <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, but can serve as reminders for the players that caused the <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> and can provide clues to other players of the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters'</link></style> abilities to other players.

<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> typically requires the updating of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style> or special <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, or at least special components in those provided for viewing <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> is a way to make <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> advance <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> of games. Especially the use of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> can be a clear way of combining the development of the character with the development of the story. Even if <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> can both modulate <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> can make these two patterns be part of <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> from a narrative perspective even if it is not so from a gameplay perspective.

<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> is a form of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style> that, quite obviously, affects <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. When the <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> are parts of <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> it equally obviously affects <style="Link"><link="team-development">Team Development</link></style>. It can provide players with <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style> simply since they do not need to consider rules regarding specific <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> or abilities before their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> have them (as long as no other <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> have them earlier). For games that rely on player skills, <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> is likely to modulate <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style> since it typically augments the possibilities of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> to affect the gameplay.

When players are aware that <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can occur, and especially when they can follow explicitly how close they are to significant development, make the development into an <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> and something which they can feel provides a <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style> - while this may be the case in any type of game it is even more so in games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> since there is no predetermined limit on how long the effort will valuable and since other players may notice the effort. When players have some <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> over the development this is quite likely to lead to <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> this gives. If players are given significant amount of control or have this <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> before gameplay begins, it gives <style="Link"><link="player-created-characters">Player-Created Characters</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can easily lead to <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style> and the use of <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>, especially when it is based on <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> activities.

The introduction of <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> are examples of <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> and can over time produce <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Paper-Rock-Scissors">Paper-Rock-Scissors</link></style> structures that provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style> between playing different <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>. Any <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can give an <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, but is perhaps most common when players are provided with <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style> - especially when these are <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can upset <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> since players that have played more or started to play earlier than <style="Link"><link="late-arriving-players">Late Arriving Players</link></style> are likely to have better <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can in any <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Game</link></style> cause conflict with <style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> but the issue becomes more pronounced for <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>). This can in turn lead to <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> can be planned as part of <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, it can in itself create <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>. Similarly, while <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style> can be designed to be options in the allowed structures for <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style>, making improvements due to <style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> into  <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> also makes them into a form of <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Character Development</style> between game or play sessions are a form of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style> that not only passes the original <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> between sessions but also introduces changes. When this is accessible, it is a form of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="abstract-player-construct-development">Abstract Player Construct Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="exaggerated-perception-influence">Exaggerated Perception of Influence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gameplay-statistics">Gameplay Statistics</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Trans-Game%20Information">Trans-Game Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="value-effort">Value of Effort</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="varying-rule-sets">Varying Rule Sets</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-levels">Character Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="character-defining-actions">Character Defining Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characteristics">Characteristics</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Leveling">Leveling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Classes">Character Classes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diminishing%20Returns">Diminishing Returns</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enforced-agent-behavior">Enforced Agent Behavior</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="playing-lose">Playing to Lose</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="skills">Skills</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="player-balance">Player Balance</link></style> when used together with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>
